heroic_journey.title: The Hero's Journey (Monomyth)
heroic_journey.author: Joseph Campbell
heroic_journey.source: The Hero with a Thousand Faces (1949)

stages.name: The Ordinary World
stages.description: The hero's normal life before the adventure begins. This establishes the hero's background, capabilities, outlook, and the mundane world they inhabit before the journey transforms them.

stages.name: The Call to Adventure
stages.description: The hero is presented with a problem, challenge, or adventure to undertake. This disrupts the comfort of their ordinary world.

stages.name: Refusal of the Call
stages.description: The hero refuses the adventure because of hesitation, fears, insecurity, or any other number of issues that prevent them from facing the unknown.

stages.name: Supernatural Aid
stages.description: Once the hero has committed to the quest, a mentor or magical helper appears or becomes known to provide supernatural aid, guidance, or a magical gift.

stages.name: Crossing the First Threshold
stages.description: The hero commits to leaving the ordinary world and enters the special world or unknown. They cross into the field of adventure, leaving the known limits of their world.

stages.name: Belly of the Whale
stages.description: The hero is fully separated from their known world and self. This represents a form of self-annihilation and rebirth. The hero is swallowed into the unknown.

stages.name: The Road of Trials
stages.description: The hero faces tests, tasks, or ordeals that must be overcome. They often fail one or more of these tests, which are repeated until success is achieved.

stages.name: The Meeting with the Goddess
stages.description: The hero experiences unconditional love, often represented by a powerful female figure. This represents the point when the hero experiences a love that has the power to inspire.

stages.name: Temptation
stages.description: The hero faces temptations, often of a physical or material nature, that may lead them to abandon or stray from their quest. This tests the hero's ability to focus on the spiritual goal.

stages.name: Atonement with the Father
stages.description: The hero must confront whatever holds ultimate power in their life. This is often a father figure or authority that has power over life and death.

stages.name: Apotheosis
stages.description: The hero achieves a period of rest, peace, and fulfillment before beginning the return. This is the point of realization and greater understanding. The hero dies to their old self.

stages.name: The Ultimate Boon
stages.description: The hero achieves the goal of the quest. This is the achievement of the goal or the object of the quest. It is what the hero went on the journey to get.

stages.name: Refusal of the Return
stages.description: Having found bliss and enlightenment in the other world, the hero may be reluctant to return to the ordinary world to bestow the boon upon their fellow humans.

stages.name: The Magic Flight
stages.description: If the boon has been achieved against the opposition of its guardian, the hero's return may be complicated by pursuit and escape. The hero must retain the wisdom gained during the quest.

stages.name: Rescue from Without
stages.description: The hero may need powerful guides and rescuers to bring them back to everyday life, especially if they have been wounded or weakened by their experience.

stages.name: The Crossing of the Return Threshold
stages.description: The hero must retain the wisdom gained on the quest and integrate that wisdom into a human life, while sharing the wisdom with the rest of the world.

stages.name: Master of Two Worlds
stages.description: The hero achieves balance between the material and spiritual, the inner and outer worlds. They have become comfortable and competent in both worlds.

stages.name: Freedom to Live
stages.description: The hero is free from fears and anxieties. They live in the moment, neither anticipating the future nor regretting the past. This is mastery of life.
